qas.question: Which two royals were part of the dynastic conflict of the 15th century?

answers.text: Isabella I of Castile and Joanna La Beltraneja

qas.question: The subsequent reforms were coined as "doma del Reino de Galicia" by who?
What was the name of the local government and tribunal?

answers.text: Real Audiencia del Reino de Galicia

context: On the other hand, the lack of an effective royal justice system in the Kingdom led to the social conflict known as the <a0_0>Guerras Irmandiñas<a0_0/> ('Wars of the brotherhoods'), when leagues of peasants and burghers, with the support of a number of knights, noblemen, and under legal protection offered by the remote king, toppled many of the castles of the Kingdom and briefly drove the noblemen into Portugal and Castile. Soon after, in the late 15th century, in the dynastic conflict between <a1_0>Isabella I of Castile and Joanna La Beltraneja<a1_0/>, part of the Galician aristocracy supported Joanna. After Isabella's victory, she initiated an administrative and political reform which the chronicler <a2_0>Jeronimo Zurita<a2_0/> defined as "doma del Reino de Galicia": 'It was then when the taming of Galicia began, because not just the local lords and knights, but all the people of that nation were the ones against the others very bold and warlike'. These reforms, while establishing a local government and tribunal (the <a3_0>Real Audiencia del Reino de Galicia<a3_0/>) and bringing the nobleman under submission, also brought most Galician monasteries and institutions under Castilian control, in what has been criticized as a process of centralisation. At the same time the kings began to call the Xunta or Cortes of the Kingdom of Galicia, an assembly of deputies or representatives of the cities of the Kingdom, to ask for monetary and military contributions. This assembly soon developed into the voice and legal representation of the Kingdom, and the depositary of its will and laws.
